clean_story:
Fresh eyes. Faster progress.

The "beginner’s advantage" describes how newcomers often outperform experts by asking obvious questions or trying simple solutions others overlook.

Experts see complexity. Beginners see the core.

A 2010 study found that chess novices spotted unconventional moves 30% faster than grandmasters—because they weren’t trapped by "this never works" assumptions.

In 1997, a first-time sailor designed a faster boat by ignoring "unwritten rules" about hull shapes. His design won races.

Beginners test basics first. Experts skip them.

The advantage fades as knowledge grows—but the lesson remains: Start before you’re ready.

Unlearning.

First principles.

The power of "why not?"
